awd_titl_txt: Parallel Encoding of Sequence and Structure in a Motor Memory Trace
awd_abstract_narration:
The purpose of this project is to elucidate how serial order is coded by the brain.  If you were to read this sentence aloud, you would utter a precise, ordered sequence of over 50 distinct vocal sounds in less than 10 seconds.  How does the brain store the individual sounds of speech and then coordinate the production of these sounds in a meaningful order so quickly?  A similar question could be asked about the pianist performing a Mozart sonata, the songs of birds, or the mating dances of insects.  How the brain stores these elaborate sequences of behavior remains unknown.  Using the songbird zebra finch, a model organism that learns meaningful sequences of vocal sounds like humans do, the interdisciplinary research team will test the hypothesis that the brain encodes and stores sequences of behavior through two separate mechanisms that operate in parallel: one coding mechanism for the sequence of vocal sounds and one for the vocal sounds themselves.  Given the diversity of animal species that display elaborate, meaningful sequences of behavior, the findings will influence understanding across a broad array of organisms, including humans.  The research plan coordinates the activity of a faculty research team from four different disciplines (Neuroanatomy, Neurophysiology, Mathematics, and Statistics) and will provide students with a unique interdisciplinary training opportunity and environment.  

Observed in nearly all animal forms (and exemplified by human speech) serial order in behavior consists of learning to organize a set of elemental gestural units into a purposeful sequence of action. Adult male zebra finches (Taeniopygia guttata) produce a highly quantifiable example of serial order in behavior (birdsong).  Moreover, a premotor cortical region (HVC, proper name) is known to encode a consolidated premotor trace of song. Although consisting of similar cell types, the medial and lateral portions of HVC are hypothesized to encode the sequence (medial HVC) and syllables (lateral HVC) of song in parallel. The research team will test whether these two dimensions of song are encoded by physiological differences in 1) afferent input to medial and lateral HVC, or 2) the intrinsic network properties of medial and lateral HVC (or a combination of 1 and 2). However, parallel encoding of serial order in behavior should be hierarchical, with traces for sequence in a supervisory position over traces for elemental gestural units. The team will also test whether efferent axons emanating from medial and lateral HVC interact in a hierarchical fashion within vocal-motor cortex. Results will elucidate a network architecture for serial order in behavior and provide a computational platform to understand how learning new sequences shapes such memory architectures.

por.por_cntn:
PROJECT OUTCOMES REPORT

IOS 1456965

Parallel Encoding of Sequence and Structure in a Motor Memory Trace

Exemplified by human speech and birdsong, the social imitation of meaningful sequences of vocal sounds involves acts of 1.) hearing a conspecific produce a sequence of individual vocal sounds, 2.) forming an auditory memory of the sound sequence, and 3.) referencing the auditory memory during vocal practice to form a motor memory that directs production of a copy of the sound sequence.  Juvenile male zebra finches (Taeniopygia guttata) acquire their songs in this manner, learning to imitate the song of an adult male.  In this project, an interdisciplinary team that included behavioral, neurobiological, mathematical, and statistical expertise asked whether the motor memory for adult male zebra finch songs is encoded in a parallel fashion, with separate memory traces for individual vocal sounds (the song notes) and for the sequence in which they are produced (the song pattern).  A novel, visually-guided surgical approach was developed to map the organization of the brain network that controls zebra finch song patterns with unprecedented precision.  Results demonstrated that the song network is organized in a massively parallel fashion and could theoretically support the multiple, parallel streams of neural activity needed to encode individual syllables and their sequence in parallel. 

An overarching project goal was to elucidate processes at single-neuron and population levels and then transform that understanding into the universal language of mathematics and computation.  Thus, a mathematical model of the song network, based on the newly discovered parallel architecture and constrained by behavioral and electrophysiological data, was constructed to demonstrate how parallel encoding of adult birdsong could be implemented within the song network.  Moreover, because the song network is bilateral (present within each brain hemisphere) a second mathematical model was developed to understand how the two halves the brain interact and take turns in directing the production of individual syllables and their sequence. 

An important yet wholly unanticipated finding made during this project was the discovery of a neural song network within the brain of adult female zebra finches.  Female zebra finches form auditory memories of song (used to recognize males) but do not produce songs themselves.  Long thought to lack many of the brain regions and neural connections that form the male song network, the same novel surgical approach used to map the male song network in unprecedented detail was applied to females.  Although the brain regions that comprise the song network in females are generally smaller than they are in males, all the connections necessary to produce song in adult males were also found in adult females.  Moreover, the physiological responses of some neurons in the female song network were found to show a striking similarity to those found in males.  These findings suggest that the smaller female song network may represent an "auditory memory only" configuration of the network, meaning that the brain regions that form the male network may be larger simply because they encode both auditory and motor memories for song in parallel.  In total, the project resulted in 5 peer-reviewed publications, the last of which was an invited review that placed the project′s findings in the context of other contemporary findings in the field of avian neurobiology.

In terms of broader impacts, the project′s activities played a significant role in the doctoral dissertations of 3 PhD graduates and 1 current PhD student.  Notably, the 3 PhD graduates (1 African American male, 1 Hispanic male, 1 Hispanic female) are now contributing to the diversification of the scientific workforce.  Modeled after the interdisciplinary character of the project team, project personnel also led a 4-year effort to develop and implement an interdisciplinary undergraduate STEM degree in Neuroscience at their home institution.  This degree is quickly becoming the most popular STEM degree on campus for female undergraduate students, thus addressing a broader societal need for institutions of higher education to offer STEM degrees that are attractive to women.  Project personnel also developed and led 2 community education courses for senior citizens, who are traditionally underserved in science education.  One course focused on the behavioral neurobiology of birdsong whereas the other focused on the brain mechanisms of learning and memory.  Both courses received overwhelmingly positive reviews from the attendees.
